messages: 86b6993ff21eaea4086c08d713cdcd1b (02:13): -hspaans: Thx. have you had the chance to play with non-global zones?

f5e97c3a9fc6d098cf09f6a69a4f43aa (02:17): +e1butch, no not really, our zones need to make money so they work instead of playing
f5e97c3a9fc6d098cf09f6a69a4f43aa (02:20): +ACTION has the same feeling like the days before christmas
86b6993ff21eaea4086c08d713cdcd1b (02:22): -Ok - i put the intro / setup to the following url http://www.but.ch/root/zone.txt
f5e97c3a9fc6d098cf09f6a69a4f43aa (02:25): +e1butch, where is the NAT?
17352d2e1d592b2f0610db85510f8012 (02:26): -e1butch, from your URL I'm guessing you're trying to set up your non-global zones in a non-routable network, with the global zone routing to the outside?
86b6993ff21eaea4086c08d713cdcd1b (02:26): -hspaans: NAT is working - because my laptop resides behind 10.1.200.110 with the real ip 10.1.200.196.
86b6993ff21eaea4086c08d713cdcd1b (02:26): -hspaans: my nat looks like: ipnat -l
86b6993ff21eaea4086c08d713cdcd1b (02:26): -List of active MAP/Redirect filters:
86b6993ff21eaea4086c08d713cdcd1b (02:27): -hspaans: You must thinking of the missing nat rule for the 172.10.20.10.

86b6993ff21eaea4086c08d713cdcd1b (02:28): -hspaans: Yes - you are right. This is not configure yet. But without the proper nat configured, I should at least be able snooping packets at the 80.254.178.109 interface leaving the nic.
86b6993ff21eaea4086c08d713cdcd1b (02:28): -hspaans: Actually - there is a 80.254.178.106 linux box available I am using for test purposes.
f5e97c3a9fc6d098cf09f6a69a4f43aa (02:28): +e1butch, why should you?
86b6993ff21eaea4086c08d713cdcd1b (02:29): -hspaans: There is abslolutely no ip packet arriving at 80.254.178.106 if originated from the non-global zone 10.1.200.111 or 172.10.20.10
86b6993ff21eaea4086c08d713cdcd1b (02:30): -hspaans: There are ip packets arriving, if originated from the global-zone (80.254.178.109) or the non-global zone 80.254.178.107
f5e97c3a9fc6d098cf09f6a69a4f43aa (02:30): +e1butch, routing is being done in the global zone
f5e97c3a9fc6d098cf09f6a69a4f43aa (02:31): +e1butch, but I currently wonder if Solaris still has stack per NIC or a shared stack like Linux. this may change some things in thinking

86b6993ff21eaea4086c08d713cdcd1b (02:33): -hspaans: The global-zone "knows" all NIC's. The non-global zones receive a "virtual" interface - commonly referred as <iface:1> or in my case qfe7:1 or similar
86b6993ff21eaea4086c08d713cdcd1b (02:33): -hspaans: I consider from what I have learned the last hours, that the Solaris10 stack is shared.
a52cfbb622e51e16f2dd4351288d4374 (02:34): +ugh. finally

86b6993ff21eaea4086c08d713cdcd1b (02:34): -hspaans: If you are ever connected to a non-global zone, just type "arp -a" and "netstat -rn". If you see foreign interfaces you know, that you are in an non-global zone.
f5e97c3a9fc6d098cf09f6a69a4f43aa (02:35): +e1butch, you can also type in `zonename' ;-)
f5e97c3a9fc6d098cf09f6a69a4f43aa (02:36): +e1butch, which sol10 are you using?
86b6993ff21eaea4086c08d713cdcd1b (02:36): -SunOS nama 5.11 snv_28 sun4u sparc SUNW,Ultra-Enterprise
f5e97c3a9fc6d098cf09f6a69a4f43aa (02:37): +e1butch, joy nemo ;-)
f5e97c3a9fc6d098cf09f6a69a4f43aa (02:38): +e1butch, sol10 and sol11 differ in part of routing in zones and stack/nic
86b6993ff21eaea4086c08d713cdcd1b (02:38): -hspaans: I am using OpenSolaris - therefore the 5.11

86b6993ff21eaea4086c08d713cdcd1b (02:40): -hspaans: If you google arround, you will come to references, where they talk about static arp entries of the default gateway. I have already used this technique without success.
f5e97c3a9fc6d098cf09f6a69a4f43aa (02:41): +e1butch, I haven't pushed 5.11 that far, but reviewing the nemo project may help you
86b6993ff21eaea4086c08d713cdcd1b (02:42): -hspaans: btw - what makes you sure `zonename` will help you understand, If you are within a non-global or global zone?
f5e97c3a9fc6d098cf09f6a69a4f43aa (02:44): +e1butch, because it should tell you the name of the zone and that should be "global" or the name of non-global zone
f5e97c3a9fc6d098cf09f6a69a4f43aa (02:45): +or write a small C-appl that does a getzoneid() if I recall correctly
